div.p:
—It was
recently rumored that the celebrated Baron Hum-
boldt was taking an interest in spirit-rappings,
table turnings, &c.; and accordingly a friend, one
Dr. Jobard, wrote a letter to the venerable sa-
vant, on the subject. Here is the reply:

“Dear Sir: You wrote, as always, a most
amiable letter, but I am unable to discuss the
simple possibility of different kinds of mineral,
vegetable, animal, voluntary and involuntary
celebral electricism. I had always the weakness
of having a dread of the spiritualism of pine
deals and of psychrographicpsychographic mysticism. You
augment my dread by the ghost of an ephemeral
rational being, which is to get understanding by
the thoughts of the men surrounding the instru-
ment, (the mediums around the table.) You
know that Geoffroy de St. Hilaire believed he
had in Egypt, had a transpiration of oxydated
thoughts; and you, dear Doctor, will perhaps
find that my skepticism is the result of my lazi-
ness. I submit to this rebuke, but I am convinc-
ed that the regret which I feel in knowing that
you have gone astray on such a dark pathway
will not diminish the friendship which you have
allowed me to enjoy for so long. I trust that
you will excuse me.
